stream_context.summary: Kaze designed a new seesaw mechanic for a factory level, which involved creating a scripted animation for a Goomba. A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to diagnosing and fixing major N64-specific issues, including a critical performance bottleneck and a complex compiler-related crash. He concluded by modeling a new construction worker Whomp enemy.

development_findings.summary: New, more expressive Tox Box models have been implemented in the game.
Kaze prefers designing levels as separate worlds connected by an overworld rather than an interconnected world like Banjo-Tooie to avoid excessive backtracking.
development_findings.quote: Having it the way Banjo-Tooie did it means you add a lot of backtracking and I don't like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is iterating on the visual design for 'glass stars' (used star markers), aiming for a look that is clearly 'used up' without being misleading to the player.
development_findings.quote: You want me to make the transparent star to look the same as the normal one with the eyes closed? Nah, that's awful. It looks way too misleading.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is involved in reviewing submissions for a community event (F3) and is impressed by the quality, particularly a game made for a calculator.
development_findings.quote: This might become a pretty hype f3 again.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to create a simplified collision map for the large factory level as a key optimization strategy to improve performance.
development_findings.quote: The game is going to have to process a lot less collision triangles.

development_findings.summary: A new construction worker Whomp enemy is being designed with a helmet on its back, intended to be its weak point, subverting the design of other enemies.
The game requires the N64 Expansion Pak to run, likely due to the size and complexity of the levels and assets.
A playtest was recently conducted for Course 2, which resulted in unspecified changes being made to the level.
development_findings.quote: I had a playtest happen on Course 2 in Return to Yoshi's Island. We've made some changes there.

context_findings.summary: Kaze intentionally streams on his secondary 'Kaze Clips' channel to interact with a dedicated community and avoid diluting the algorithm on his main channel with niche development content.
context_findings.quote: I just care about making a good game. If you get entertained that's a side effect.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed that a significant sponsorship deal with Brilliant has ended, impacting his YouTube profitability and adding a layer of financial pressure to his work.
context_findings.quote: My youtube channel is barely profitable, especially now that brilliant doesn't sponsor me anymore kind of back to square zero.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes that well-written code is self-documenting and that redundant comments are unnecessary.
context_findings.quote: The code itself is better documentation than your documentation so you should remove your documentation.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed genuine excitement and pride over significant improvements he made to the game's collision engine, making it far more stable than the original Mario 64.
context_findings.quote: You see how stable that is? Mario 64 would never be able to handle this. Like a surface like this in Mario 64 is deadly and would never work correctly. I love this.

context_findings.summary: The lore for the factory level has evolved during development, shifting from a specific 'Fleet Factory' to a more general refueling station for Bowser's army.
context_findings.quote: I'm not helping you. Is this meant to be a factory making airship parts or just an all right currency with the lore? It was supposed to be like Bozo's Fleet Factory at first, but it slowly became just like the place where they tank up, I guess.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is simultaneously developing a massive level called 'Only Up 64' for a community competition hosted by SimpleFlips, demonstrating his engagement with the broader Mario 64 community.
Kaze expressed frustration with the Parallel Launcher emulator and stated he will no longer provide support for it, focusing instead on Project64 and real hardware.
context_findings.quote: Parallel launcher users are like the Linux users of the Mario 64 hacking world.

biobak.summary: Biobak was present in the stream chat and showed a clear understanding of Kaze's development process and humor, correctly identifying a scripted animation as 'YouTube physics'.
biobak.quote: It's a real-time simulation physics for the YouTube clip, namely. Yep, Biobak understands the assignment.

badub.summary: Badub, the composer, has been temporarily unavailable, which has left the music for a new enemy character in limbo.
badub.quote: I thought Badub was gonna make him song but Badub's been missing in attendance for a bit so I'm not really sure what to expect there.

zeina.summary: Zeina has already created most of the animations for the 'cement pit guy' enemy, indicating her animation work is proceeding in parallel with Kaze's programming.
zeina.quote: Zeina made the animations for this guy already or most of them.

zeina.summary: Kaze made a joke suggesting Zeina is particularly protective of certain creative assets, in this case the Yoshi model.
zeina.quote: I touched her right in the Yoshi. She would not let anyone else touch the Yoshi.

key_stories.title: N64 Performance Optimization
key_stories.summary: Kaze faced a critical performance bottleneck in a large level on N64 hardware. He devised a clever, platform-specific solution, enabling backface culling only on the console to drastically improve framerates while preserving his preferred visual style for emulator players.
key_stories.challenge: A large, complex factory level was performing poorly on original N64 hardware, with framerates dropping to an unplayable 19 FPS in certain areas.
key_stories.process: Kaze diagnosed the issue as a large number of polygons on metal scaffolding being rendered without backface culling. He implemented a conditional fix to enable backface culling on specific materials only when the game is running on N64, boosting performance without compromising the visual style on emulators.
key_stories.outcome: The level's performance on N64 was significantly improved to a playable 25-29 FPS. The solution allows the game to look its best on emulators while being optimized for the constraints of original hardware.
key_stories.key_quote: I actually prefer the without backface calling version on emulator, but on N64 I can see how this looks better. I think the backface visibility is gonna be an emulator only thing here.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Compiler Bug
key_stories.summary: A mysterious crash that only occurred on N64 hardware led Kaze to discover a subtle but critical issue with the compiler. It was aggressively reordering code in a way that bypassed his safety checks, forcing him to debug at the assembly level and rewrite his code to outsmart the compiler.
key_stories.challenge: The game was crashing on N64 hardware with a division-by-zero error, but not on the Project 64 emulator. The crash occurred in code Kaze had specifically written to prevent that exact error.
key_stories.process: After the initial fix failed, Kaze inspected the compiled MIPS assembly code. He discovered the compiler was aggressively optimizing by executing the division instruction in the 'branch delay slot' of his safety check, nullifying the check entirely. He had to rewrite the C code to work around this compiler behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully fixed the crash by restructuring his C code to prevent the compiler from making the problematic optimization. The incident serves as a stark example of the low-level challenges of console development.
key_stories.key_quote: Basically, the compiler decided that right here, where I want to avoid the division by 0, it is going to pipeline the division into the delay slot of my branch. So that no matter what happens, I always divide by 0. That's not a bug in the code. That is not my fault.

key_stories.title: Designing the Seesaw Goomba
key_stories.summary: Kaze designed a new enemy interaction from concept to completion in-stream. He created a seesaw that, when triggered by the player, falls and comically flattens a Goomba, showcasing his iterative process of creating small, satisfying gameplay moments.
key_stories.challenge: To create a new, unique, and satisfying environmental interaction for the factory level that fit the theme of 'messing with' enemies.
key_stories.process: Kaze designed a scenario with a Goomba on a seesaw. He modeled the seesaw and programmed its behavior, opting for a scripted animation over a complex physics simulation for predictability. He iterated on the falling speed and bounce until the effect was just right, culminating in the seesaw plank falling and flattening the Goomba.
key_stories.outcome: A complete and polished micro-interaction was created. Kaze was extremely pleased with the final result, particularly the comical animation of the Goomba being squished.
key_stories.key_quote: Alright, the final image is beautiful. Like it ending like this is the best thing ever. I love this.
